order to parse the different ways you might be logging um and in general my
recommendation for logging is every time you show a web page or do some action every ID that potentially appears on
that page should also appear in your log so you have a really good idea of what was going on in that page uh the example
here is a hypothetical search query log and uh in it we have the user ID that
made the the request what the terms of the search query was but perhaps most importantly the results that were
returned from that query what business IDs uh were returned from that and from those business IDs you could calculate
things like click-through rate um relevance all that sort of thing and if you don't log those you may know that uh
table uh Farm to Table was a popular query that month but you won't know what uh businesses showed up for it or or
what people ended up clicking on so making sure to uh to log all that information is very important the
exception is uh personally identifiable information uh we'll talk about why that
is in in general but uh you want your logs to be accessible to as many people as possible and if you put in pii info
you limit the number of people the number of ways that that log can be used so instead what I recommend is again
sticking to IDs so put your pii in a database and then in the log you put an
ID that kind of points to that database and in the future if you need to join against uh pii for some analytics reason

cluster we had um and it was working really well so I have a riddle when do

so failing is a great example of success and the reason is now you have too many
users using your solution and this is exactly what happened at Yelp we had Hadoop it was working fairly well um but
people were starting to complain uh and experience problems because we were so overwhelmed by the number of things that
people wanted to do um and some of those issues specifically uh were failures
correlated with cluster time so if we ran a Hadoop cluster for a long amount of time we would see memory leaks we
would see other issues um and eventually that cluster would slow down or break in
very weird ways um and when we wanted to launch new features that depended on
doing this log processing we often had to coordinate with other teams so we had to say oh are are you using the cluster
right now or what time are you using the cluster I want to use I want to have this new feature and it's going to

other teams for when uh infrastructure upgrades Could Happen was uh one of the
pain points that we experienced
there so with all of these problems um we wanted some specific Solutions and
when we looked at EMR uh we found a lot of these Solutions uh and that was the reason why we decided to migrate um so
clusters were up for a limited amount of time right you spin up a cluster to need it it shuts down when you're done you

accumulated memory loss sorry accumulated um memory leaks uh upgrades
are obviously handled by Amazon and again you didn't have to bring down a cluster because you're bringing up and

test on Hadoop itself to make sure our general libraries work uh that any um

trying to uh pretend like you're cloud ready but not actually taking any uh

using so the way it works with Mr job um is that there's a standard configuration
file that all people use and when a cluster is spun up it picks the number
uh the bootstrap actions that install common packages um and push a particular
version of the Yelp code base um that is standardized across all production
builds when you launch a cluster um Mr job copies a tarball to EMR expands it
and then sets up the correct python environment so all of those libraries are available and the configurations we have
um are a standard one that's great for most jobs uh a memory intensive one where we expect say reducers to
accumulate a lot of data in memory before being able to process and then a CPU intensive one um that allows uh
people who who need a lot of CPU raw CPU power in order to power through their jobs and this is a small uh subsample of
the configuration that we use for Mr job and as you can see um for example for
the the standard jobs we have we use M1 five M1 larges for a memory intensive uh
we use M1 extra larges 12 of them and we have some additional bootstrap actions
that set up a swap partition um as well as uh use Amazon's standard uh
configuration for Hadoop to increase the amount of memory available to each reducer and mapper and then finally the
C1 or sorry finally the CPU intensive job uses C1 uh extra larges as another
kind of side note here we did some some playing around with these numbers to to make sure they were kind of generally
optimal one of the things that we saw which may have changed over time is that actually increasing the number of
machines that we use for example um 12 M1 extra larges was still more efficient
uh latency wise um than using say M2 extra larges or 4X larges or something
like that because the number of machines allows uh you to suck down data from S3
in parallel much more easily um and so the way we do resource
tracking as another example um is using a uh side utility of Mr job which checks
um the the jobs that are currently running in EMR and how long they've been running so
if something's been running over a day uh the general Hadoop list gets an email saying hey are you sure you want to be
running this over a day um because that is is in our environment that's fairly uncommon for you guys it might be
different we might want to do something else um and another way that we uh uh
make sure that we don't kind of have Runway jobs is uh Mr job has another utility that looks for idle job Flows In
job flows that are not doing anything right now and it'll terminate those uh after a certain period of time it'll
actually terminate them close to the hour mark So potentially if someone wants to reuse that cluster we're able
to um and then in general when uh EMR sorry Mr job is pushing up um uh new job
flows it'll label them by the developer that's uh that's running the job or uh
or the specific batch that's running so when you look over uh the usage of EMR
you can associate different batches with teams and understand how much resources each team is
using and finally uh for testing Mr job has this local mode and you actually run
it in the exact same way that you'd run it in EMR the only difference is you
specify a runner so there's a local Runner and an EMR Runner you invoke it
in almost the same way um but the local one will run on uh your laptop and you

it make sure that all of the standard libraries that we'd like to be using are loadable and available and again that's

uh emario is a tool that we wrote that looks at your past usage of EMR uh and

but we found that uh that that kind of risk isn't worth the reward of any extra

write consistency or the eventual consistency of S3 even in uh what are
called consistent zones of S3 um that consistency is very very limited it's
limited to uh a git after a put of a specific new object so it does not
include things like list uh it does not include things like uh overwriting a file and uh being able to immediately

the major way we've solved this is frankly just waiting longer for the consistency to get up to
date um closed Source uh is a concern for us
um with Hadoop it's been very easy to look at the source see what's going on uh but when we encountered a problem
that used some of the uh source code that Amazon provides specifically uh
uploading the result of Hadoop jobs to S3 uh we were encountering a problem
where we'd see files kind of partially overwritten or empty um and what this
turned out to be was a hadoop's speculative execution where if a
particular map or reduce step was taking a long time it would try to spin up another one and what would happen is
both of those would try to write to the same S3 bucket uh S3 key rather and
you'd get uh inconsistency at the key level you you'd sometimes get an empty key there um because of some of these
issues and for us it was almost impossible to debug because we couldn't look at the code which was actually
doing the uploading so it was very hard to narrow down and we had to work with uh Amazon's help desk in order to track
this down and going back and forth across two organizations can be much slower than one team investigating a

intermittent problem uh I think it ended up taking uh two or three weeks to actually resolve the solution by the way
uh and I think this has been propagated to standard bootstrap actions but is to turn off speculative execution in Hadoop
here um and finally uh as again as we've been using this technology more and more
um we've kind of exploded the number of data sources that we've had um and when
we do uploads of MySQL uh uploads of that information um we need to keep
